editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A SERMON PREACHED IN THE CITIE OF LONDON By a Lover of Truth. Touching the Power of a KING, and proving out of the Word of GOD, that the Authoritie of a King is onely from GOD and not of Man.

q.p: Where the word of a King is there is power, and who may Å¿ay unto him, what doest thou.

div.p: London Printed 1643.

q.p: Where the word of a King is there is power, And who may Å¿ay unto him what doeÅ¿t thou.

div.p: BEfore I Å¿hall adventure to apply this Text (for to expound it is needleÅ¿Å¿e) to Å¿uch perÅ¿ons both in Towne and Countrie who make it their only Religion to but prate rebellious queÅ¿tions concerning the priviledges and actions of Kings; I were beÅ¿t bee aÅ¿Å¿ured I can prove my Text to be the expreÅ¿Å¿e Word of God, or elÅ¿e thoÅ¿e people who queÅ¿tion Kings will be Å¿ure to queÅ¿tion me.

There is but one that ever queÅ¿tioned this Preacher, and if Tertullians rule be true Quicunque eÅ¿t unus eÅ¿t haereticus, wee muÅ¿t rather aÅ¿Å¿ent to the generall tradition of antiquitie: by the words you will know that one to bee Martin Luther, he Å¿aith this booke is like a man on horÅ¿e-backe without boots or Å¿purres, never keeping a certaine pace: but you all know the driving of that man was like Iehu, he drave furiouÅ¿ly both againÅ¿t Church and Kings. Every Å¿pirit that moved not Luther pace, bee it the Å¿pirit of Solomon the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t prince in the world, yea although that Å¿pirit be a freÅ¿h inÅ¿pired by Gods Å¿pirit, yet CeÅ¿Å¿ator eÅ¿t & ego: calcaribus but of the two rather thinke Luthors tounge wanted a bridle wee therefore in the
feare of God and authority of his holy Church will acknowledge the Å¿pirit and power of God to be in this booke, and in this Text ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , and will Å¿ay unto our King in the words of the PÅ¿alme Ride on we wiÅ¿h thee good lucke in the name of the Lord.

div.head: Where the word of a King, &c.
div.p: IT is well wee finde in Scipture terminis terminentibus, or elÅ¿e wee might have loÅ¿t him. Ego dixi dij eÅ¿tis, there might be Å¿ome evaÅ¿ions hence, there is mention of Judges and under-MagiÅ¿trates in the Land PÅ¿alme 82.6. they might aÅ¿Å¿ume this unqueÅ¿tioned power and queÅ¿tion thoÅ¿e whom we call Kings. Saint Paul he names Å¿ome in authority, but the Pope may come in for his supremacie. In the latter time there are Calvins, MagiÅ¿tratus, Populares, Beza's, Å¿uperiores poteÅ¿tates, Brutus, Iunius optimates regni, Daneus ordines regni, Buchanus publica adminiÅ¿trationis participes. AlthaÅ¿ius, Ephori, Paraus inferiores potestates, Å¿o many names as head of the beaÅ¿t in the Apocalip. But here wee have Melecke a King, be not Å¿ubject to Å¿ubjects or inferiour MagiÅ¿trates, but Å¿ubjecti estote regi tanquam Å¿upereminenti, 1 Pet. 2.13.

Whence and what Kings are, are doctrines I thinke Å¿utable both to this Text and theÅ¿e times, their originall is from God a good beginning. Per me reges regnant
ã in non-Latin alphabet ã Å¿aith Saint ChryÅ¿ostome. The ancient forme of Å¿alutation uÅ¿ed by the BiÅ¿hop of Rome was In eo per quem reges regnant, then was it not his owne holineÅ¿Å¿e Rex regum is written upon ChriÅ¿t owne thigh Apoc. 19.16. and MelchiÅ¿edeck his owne firÅ¿t type and King was ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , without father or Mother. Kings are not the offÅ¿pring of man but the generation of God, Ego dixi Dij eÅ¿tis. God help Kings if people undertake to make them, if they may turne Gods verÅ¿e, to nos diximus Dij eÅ¿tis; if they may change ChriÅ¿ts words, from thou Å¿houldest have no power over mee unleÅ¿Å¿e it were given thee from above, to, thou Å¿houldst have no power over me unleÅ¿Å¿e it were granted thee de Å¿ubter, from beneath. No all Kings and Kingdomes are Gods. Cujus juÅ¿Å¿u naÅ¿cunter homines, ejus juÅ¿Å¿u ConÅ¿tituuntur Principes, Iraen: Inde Å¿uis poteÅ¿tas unde Å¿piritus. Tert. Even all their ornaments and imperiall enÅ¿ignes are from God.
Diadomae regis in manu dei, EÅ¿ay 62. His their Crowne, TupoÅ¿uiÅ¿ti, PÅ¿alme 21. Hee puts it on. The Emperours Å¿tampe on their Coines was a hand comming forth out of the Clouds holding a Crowne, putting it on their heads. His is their Scepter, Virga dei in manibus ejus, His their Throne, Reges in Å¿olie coll â¢ cat in perpetuum, Å¿aith Iob. He faÅ¿tens them in it for ever; His alÅ¿o their annointing, Touch not mine Annointed, I have annointed David my Å¿ervant, annointed with oyle for Å¿upremacie and continuance in his Throne, not uncti. as PrieÅ¿ts, but ChriÅ¿ti Domini, Å¿aith the BiÅ¿hop of WincheÅ¿ter thirtie three times, Å¿o Å¿tiled in the Old TeÅ¿tament, and once in the New. Their manner of annointing alÅ¿o was diverÅ¿e from the PrieÅ¿ts. They were annointed on the forehead, Kings on the head Å¿aith Erotius in his annotations to CaÅ¿Å¿enders conÅ¿ultations, in a word Å¿aith Saint August. they are uncti ante unctionem, before we can touch them. v. e. decreto.

Kings whether good or bad they are from God, Per me Reges regnant was Å¿poken when there was but one good King upon the face of the earth Solomon. Haec dicit Dominus Cyro uncto meo. He a PerÅ¿ian a Heathen. It repented God of what? that he had made Saul King. Ego dedi vobis in ira mea regem, HoÅ¿. 13.11. Angry I was when I gave you, I gave him through, and there in that honour he must remains though he become Onus Populi, an heavie burthen upon the necke of all his Å¿ubjects. Nebuchadnezar who Å¿lew and kept alive whom he pleaÅ¿ed, I gave him, His MajeÅ¿ty, Dan. 9. I have raiÅ¿ed up Pharaoh and placed him in his Throne, to make my power knowne on him who had deÅ¿erved it, that is one Å¿ence whatÅ¿oever is the other. And the Holy GhoÅ¿t in Scripture Å¿tiles not only David and Salomon Kings, but takes in the reÅ¿t: Hiram, and Pharaoh, and Hadad, and where the Scripture doth not diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h neither may wee, be their religion or manners what pleaÅ¿e them, by God they are made, and may not bee marrd by the peopleâIn nature every thing is diÅ¿Å¿olved by the Å¿ame meanes it came together, in Law inÅ¿titution, and deÅ¿titution belong to one: in Divinity alÅ¿o the Prophet in one and the Å¿ame verÅ¿e Å¿aith, Ego dedi vobis regem, in the former, and in one breath, abstuli eum, in the latter, Dominus dedit & Dominus abstulit, and then, and not till then, the people to Å¿ay benedictum Å¿it nomen dei. And well it is that God hath placed
them Å¿o neere himÅ¿elfe, poÅ¿t Deum primus Å¿ecundum Deum proximi, Tert. Humani Ioves Plant: the Å¿ubiect then may not come Å¿o neere him as Nathan, to tell him tu es homo without Nathans CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, but tu es Rex, tu es Deus Terra, a God on earth, Å¿o neare and Å¿o one are Kings with God, that the accuÅ¿ation of Naboth, whereby the Å¿tory he Å¿pake nothing of God, but of the King, they bring in the verdict. Naboth, Maledixi: Deo & Regi, as if hee could not bu blaÅ¿pheme God that Å¿pake ill of his King, though of Ahab NequiÅ¿Å¿imus regum. They are much miÅ¿taken who think that God was offended with the Jewes for choÅ¿ing royall government in oppoÅ¿ition to the jud â¢ ciall or the Shawhedrim eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed by God under MoÅ¿es, for Royall government hath beene moÅ¿t ancient and univerÅ¿all in the world, in the Law of nature, before the Ta â¢ les. Saint ChriÅ¿oÅ¿tome Å¿aith therefore, Eve was taken out of man, not out of the earth, that mankinde might acknowledge one head, one Superiour, one King, and Sir Wal. Raleigh in his Å¿econd book of the HiÅ¿t. of the world, Royall Government from Paternall, which indeed are or ought to bee both in one effect, and Å¿o we reade of Abraham the Patrarch is termed a Prince, GeneÅ¿is 23.6. And David the KING is named a Patriarch, let mee Å¿peake boldly to you of David the Patriarch: jus regum comes from, jus paternum, both have one commandement, Honour thy Father, as God alone rules the whole world, and as the Sunne gives light to all creatures, Å¿o the people of one Land doe moÅ¿t naturally yeeld obedience to one head, one King. All Nations were firÅ¿t governed by this forme, AÅ¿Å¿yrians, GreÅ¿ians, Aegyptians, Iewes, Percians, Scythians, Turkes, Tartares, EngliÅ¿h, French, Spaniards, Poles, Danes, and in the Iudges; Neither doth Å¿acred Scripture make mention of other Rulers then Kings. He that will know more in Å¿o cleere a caÅ¿e, may if he pleaÅ¿e read Plato, Herodotus, Zen â¢ phon, Saint Cyprian, Saint Ierome. Soveraignty in one perÅ¿on, is moÅ¿t naturall, moÅ¿t reaÅ¿onable, moÅ¿t honourable, moÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿ary, moÅ¿t divine; So that God was not angry at the choyce of the kinde of government, but that he thereby was caÅ¿t forth from being King of the Iewes, whom hee in the place of a King had governed for above three hundred and fiftie yeares, for neither MoÅ¿es nor the Sawhedrim nor any Judge in IÅ¿rael had in themÅ¿elves,
jus imperatorium the Right of a King, but onely jus hortatorium & punitivum, if they tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ed the written Law of God. God only was their King, who faine would Å¿till (beÅ¿ides the generall protection of the world) have ruled as an earthly King among the reÅ¿t, and a patterne to them: but they would no longer live by faith and expectation of his wonted direction in government and deliverance, but rather to be as the Nations round about them, they choÅ¿e a man and refuÅ¿ed the living GOD, Hee is ejected from his immediate Royalty. This the ground of Gods diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure at the Iewes for chooÅ¿ing them a KING. Ancient and univerÅ¿all hath beene the government of the world by Kings. Saint Ierom â¢
in one of his EpiÅ¿tles, Å¿aith that two Governours in a Common-wealth are like EÅ¿au and Iacob, two Princes in the wombe of Rebecca Å¿o they in one Kingdome, rend and teare in peeces: Rome would not endure two brothers, In navi unus guberrator in EccleÅ¿ia unus EpiÅ¿copus, in Domo unus Dominus, in exercitu unum Å¿ignum, in imperio unus imperator. The onely way to recover and preÅ¿erve unity and peace among us, is one King. This for the Originall and antiquitie of Kings whence they are and when.

Now Å¿econdly, what they are, which is beÅ¿t knowne by that whereby they are formaliter, or finaliter tales, their power: Where the Word of a King is, there is power, &c. Salomon the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t of men as well as Kings, Proverbs 8.15. placeth Kings before the Creation of the world, better not to bee at all then under no Governement, which is none without power, and that power if to any purpoÅ¿e muÅ¿t bee Å¿uch, as with which no earthly power may conteÅ¿t, the owner of it, is evermore Alkum one againÅ¿t whom there ought to bee no riÅ¿ing, nor any rebellion at all.
Darius his three Å¿ervants in EÅ¿dras wrote their wiÅ¿e Å¿entences.
1. Forte est vinum.
2. Fortis est Rex.

3. Fortiores Å¿urt mulieres; Å¿ed Å¿upra omnia eÅ¿t veritas. I am Å¿omewhat afeard it was a PropheÅ¿ie, they are indeed at this day, Å¿tronger then our Darius. Their fond PharaÅ¿aicall, and Å¿editious
religions are as ridiculous and as changeable as their faÅ¿hions and attires, their ungrounded zeales, their nouriÅ¿hing and feeding of the vulgar and rebellious of the Clergie, thoÅ¿e illiterate talkers in the Pulpit will, niÅ¿i Å¿upra omnia Å¿it veritas, if the God of truth doe not Å¿peedily offend, be Å¿tronger then either King or Church David although a man of valour and pietie, yet complaines he that the Å¿onnes of Zervia were to hard for him. But our Kings and Church may both complaine of the daughters of this Land. That they are and will be to hard for us, niÅ¿i Å¿upra omnia veritas, unleÅ¿Å¿e God Å¿upport the integrity of our King, and the Å¿incerity of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion. A more pregnant place for the power of Kings is in WiÅ¿dome 26 2. Å¿peaking of the extreme vengeance which God will bring upon the heads of evill Kings at the laÅ¿t day, he proves the certainty thereof by an argument which will Å¿eeme very Å¿trange in theÅ¿e rebellious dayes: Quoniam Dominus non vevebitur faciem cujuÅ¿que, unto you O Kings doe I Å¿peake, hee is not afraid of the perÅ¿ons of Kings, hee dares call them to account: A very vaine idle argument to prove his unmaÅ¿tered deity, and power in that he is not afraid of Kings. Who is afraid of them? Doth God indeed Å¿ay, Ego dixi Dij estis? Wee can take up the next verÅ¿e and be even with him, he Å¿hall fall when we pleaÅ¿e) like one of the Princes. No Å¿uch great matter of feare is the perÅ¿on or power of a King now a dayes, when every poore ignorant peÅ¿ant, or Å¿hop-man can define, confine, and pinch up the prerogative of the King, when the vulgar Clergie, thoÅ¿e Gibeanites, not fit to draw water for learned men, can pricke and gird the perÅ¿on of the King for the Å¿pace of three or foure houres. When every petty but inÅ¿olent Towne can neglect, if not contemne his preÅ¿ence when be vouchÅ¿afes to come and Å¿ee us. So that if God will prove his Å¿ecuritie to us, hee muÅ¿t quit the old argument of feare due unto Kings, from all but himÅ¿elfe, and fetch one Å¿utable to our late religions and governments in Church and Common-Wealth; As that he is not afraid of the Popes holineÅ¿Å¿e, or of a presbysteriall diÅ¿cipline, or a popular diÅ¿cipline. Thus Scripture and reaÅ¿on the arguments of the wiÅ¿e muÅ¿t bee turned to and fro, to follow the unconÅ¿tant humour of this preÅ¿ent world. But we in feare of God, and honour of his King, will lay the ground of our allegiance faÅ¿t, and
Å¿uch as whereupon wee may build up a peece of obedience that may procure us a Crowne of immortality at the laÅ¿t day, by Saint Gregories rule, arceÅ¿Å¿emus Rivum fidelitatis de fonte pietatis, not only from cuÅ¿tomes and fundamentall lawes in a private land, who are moÅ¿t-what both imperfect and obÅ¿cure, but from the plaine and eaÅ¿ie Text of Gods owne Law, which as it is Å¿ufficient for any mans Å¿alvation, without the blaÅ¿phemous expoÅ¿itions of theÅ¿e times. So in the point of obedience unto Kings (a maine principle in ChriÅ¿tian doctrine) without which no man Å¿hall enter into the Kingdome of heaven) it is very plentifull and plaine among the reÅ¿t, this is one, Where the word of a King is, there is power.

div.head: The word of a King.
div.p: IT is as the roaring of a Lion. It is Divalis juÅ¿Å¿io, Å¿ay the councells, Eloquium divinum eÅ¿t in ore regis, Å¿aith Salomon and Barclay cites, three fundamentall lawes in Scotland, in honour of the word of a KING. Si quis in alterius quam regis verba juraverit capitale eÅ¿to. Si quis in juÅ¿Å¿u regis (without his word) homines in armis habuerit, morte crimen, expiatur. Solius Regis nomine jus onme redditur, conventus judicatur, concilia convocanter. But I choÅ¿e rather to apply my Å¿elfe to Gods Word, and then will prove the power of the word of a King.

There are two powers of Kings plaine in two places of Gods Word, the firÅ¿t is Potestas. What hee may and ought to doe in equitie, That is Å¿et downe, In capite volum, Deut. 17. The Å¿econd is Potentia jus impunitatis, what he may doe, and yet may not be queÅ¿tioned by his Å¿ubjects for Å¿o doing. This is in, 1 Sam. 8.12. and to the 19. The former is his owne rule, as he will anÅ¿wer God if he tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿e, the latter is his peoples rule for their obedience. The former power what is religious and juÅ¿t towards God and his people, his grave Divines, and skilfull Lawyers who are about his perÅ¿on are bound to explaine. The one to rehearÅ¿e. Otho FrigenÅ¿is his Å¿entence to him or Å¿uch like concerning the day of judgment. Cum horre dum Å¿it omni mortali incidere in manus dei viventis, Regibus tamen eo erit horribilius, quo ipÅ¿i caeteris poÅ¿Å¿ent peccare liberius. They Å¿hould be informed that Kings come from ChriÅ¿ts owne thigh, Apoc. 19. On his thigh is written King of Kings,
and Lord of Lords, That they come from the thigh of God, their government ought to bee paternall and eaÅ¿ie, to uÅ¿e his Å¿ubjects as his owne Children, as God uÅ¿eth man; that they ought not to weare Reheboams fingers, much leÅ¿Å¿e his Fathers loynes, but Abrahams, yea ChriÅ¿ts loynes more compaÅ¿Å¿ionate and kinde to his people under the time of ChriÅ¿ti â¢ nitie then before: That their Scepters are not given them to diÅ¿h out the braines of their innocent Å¿ubjects, but that it was derived from Davids Å¿heep-hooke to lead his people by the waters of comfort, that the people are not to be goared with whips and Scorpions, and intolerable taxes and oppreÅ¿Å¿ions but to be led like Å¿heepe by the hands of MoÅ¿es and Aaron. That they are anointed with oyle, in token to make glad the hearts of all their Å¿ubjects, not beÅ¿meare them ore with Vineger. And not only religion, but alÅ¿o in Policie his Councellours, and Lawyers are bound in ConÅ¿cience to exhort him to keep within the bounds of equity and imperrall right. Catose counÅ¿ell oft repeated to him. Potentes parce uti debere poteÅ¿tate ut diu poÅ¿Å¿int They ought to adviÅ¿e him that few Lawes whether in Church or Common wealth are admirable preÅ¿ervatives both of Kings and kingdoms The government of the Iewes had not continued long under the Ceremoniall Law (the burden too heavie for them to beare) had not God watched over them with Å¿evere judgements. And if many Lawes be enacted, and thoÅ¿e not cloÅ¿ely united to reaÅ¿on, but only depending on the placitum of the Law-maker, if alÅ¿o thereby he tye both their ConÅ¿ciences and purÅ¿es (to which the ConÅ¿ciences of moÅ¿t men are tyed) it is not morally poÅ¿Å¿ible, but Å¿uch a kingdome by the malice of men will Å¿hortly after bee confounded. They ought to informe that he ought to rule more Turcico His people are not mancipia, nor more valdeÅ¿iano, they have poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions under him; neither ã in non-Latin alphabet ã nor ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , without fault in the Å¿ubject to be in his power: But that his Å¿ubjects are ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , in Å¿ubordination and Å¿ubjection only. That a little leaven leaveneth the whole lump a little oppreÅ¿Å¿ion makes all his Å¿ubjects Å¿ource, eÅ¿pecially if the people bee aforehand Å¿eaÅ¿oned with the leaven of the PhariÅ¿ees, with hypocriÅ¿ie, who have nothing of Religion Å¿save names of faith and tread-water-grace inÅ¿pirations, markes of Election of their owne chooÅ¿ing, reprobating
all beÅ¿ides themÅ¿elves even Kings if they pleaÅ¿e them not, having the forme of godlineÅ¿Å¿e, but denying the power thereof, even the power the Kings. The power they are bound to adviÅ¿e the King of who are imployed about his perÅ¿on; Wee who have to deale with the people are bound to deliver his Å¿ecundam power nifi impunitatis, who may Å¿ay unto the King if he doe amiÅ¿Å¿e, What doeÅ¿t thou, Kings are not to be queÅ¿tioned.

The firÅ¿t wee finde in this Å¿acrilegious, forme to MoÅ¿es a Deputie, no King was, Corah and his complices, and as their way was not the common way of obedient Å¿ubjects, Å¿o neither was their death the common death of men. For Å¿ay they could charge MoÅ¿es and Aaron with intruÅ¿ion into their rights, muÅ¿t the form needs be by the way of queÅ¿tion interrogative. Cur elevamini, there are many other wayes to have done it more meekely: and if you marke it, it is no ordinary quare lamma, but an imperious terme, umaddans, what is the reaÅ¿on; Ephori like, we require an account of the adminiÅ¿tration of the Common wealth. This Å¿aucy forme of queÅ¿tioning the Jewes kept till our Sauiours time: Is not this the Carpenters Å¿onne. Is it lawfull to pay tribute unto CaeÅ¿ar, who made thee a ruler over us. It was the DonatiÅ¿ts forme in Saint AuguÅ¿tine: Quid nobis imperatores? It is the Popes forme. It is the Presbyterians-factious form. It is the devils form of coming to Kings with inÅ¿olent queÅ¿tions? Quid agis, we expect Å¿atisfaction not the word of a King only, for what hath bin governed amiÅ¿Å¿e. Quanquam dignus Å¿it haec contum lia, &c. Here in the Text is an anÅ¿wer as large, though not as unreaÅ¿onable, and that in the Å¿ame way by way of queÅ¿tion. Who may Å¿ay unto him? 1. Quis e clero? 2. Quis ex optimatibus. 3. Quis e MagiÅ¿tratibus regni. 4. Ques e Populo? may dare Å¿ay to Him, Him annointed with oyle for Å¿upremacie and continuance in his Throne! Him! unctum but ChriÅ¿tum Domini, Him? Not man but God? what Å¿ubject? what profane perÅ¿on? what mortall man may dare Å¿ay unto him? What doeÅ¿t thou.

div.head: I. Quis e Clero
div.p:
WHo of all the Church for matters of Religion or Sacriledge may queÅ¿tion the authoritie of a King. Begin wee with our Lord and MaÅ¿ter of Religion, our Saviour ChriÅ¿t, hee Å¿uffered
not Saint Peter to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the MagiÅ¿trate: Saint AuÅ¿tin reprehends both MoÅ¿es and Saint Peter, Contra Manich: ille fraterno, hic domanico amore peccavit: nec pro fratre, nec pro ChriÅ¿to, ita
que nec pro Christi Religione eÅ¿t adverÅ¿us principes machinandi locus. Baronius to the yeare of ChriÅ¿t 350. Å¿aith that in the purer times of ChriÅ¿tians non cogitaverunt de vindicta, for Å¿aith Tertul. If malum malo diÅ¿pungi, were lawfull in ChriÅ¿tians, Nos implevimus caÅ¿tra urbes, oppida, &c. wee had all the GarriÅ¿ons and fortes of the kingdome, una nox pauculis faculis, wee could have lighted our cruell Tyrants to their graves. Saint BaÅ¿il gave up the Towne to Iulian the ApoÅ¿tate even when they might have defended themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t him, he rather by teares, and prayers, beÅ¿eecheth him to Å¿pare the ChriÅ¿tians. Famous is Saint AmbroÅ¿e in his obedience to TheodoÅ¿ius, Suadeo rogo, hortor, admoneo, no more to a King Ego in te contumaciae animam non habeo, Å¿ed habeo timoris, and when Valentine demanded his Church, he anÅ¿wers the King, that by right, thou canÅ¿t not take away the houÅ¿e of a private man (neither can be) and thinke you by your power to take away the HouÅ¿e of God, yet marke, imperatori non done, Å¿ed non nego, tradere baÅ¿ilicant poÅ¿Å¿um, Å¿ed pugnare non debeo, volens nunquam jus deÅ¿eram coactus repugnare non novi, dolere potero, potero gemire, aliter nec debeo nec poÅ¿Å¿um reÅ¿iÅ¿tere But excelling all theÅ¿e is the practice of holy Samuel towards, Saul who was neither PrieÅ¿t nor ChriÅ¿tian, I Sam. 15. when Sauls kingdome was rent from him, decreto divino, hee requeÅ¿ted Samuel to Å¿tay and intreat God for him. No, Perjecisti Sermonem domini & projecit te dominus ne Å¿is Rex Å¿uper IÅ¿rael, Saul catcheth at him and rent his mantle. Samuel replies, The Lord hath rent the kingdome of IÅ¿rael from thee this day. Then Å¿aith Saul, I have Å¿inned, honour me I pray thee before the Elders of my people: Here Samuel Å¿tayed, and returned and followed after Saul.

The vices of Idolatrie of a King may not be remonÅ¿trated or declared down to the people, by any member of the Church of God, we muÅ¿t honour him before the people and Elders in IÅ¿rael. Yea though he rend off our mantles from our backes, although hee deprive us of all our revenewes, we muÅ¿t with St. Bernard Å¿ay, if all the world Å¿hould importune me, to diÅ¿honour the perÅ¿on of Lodovicus
for his Å¿acriledge, Ego tamen Deum timerem. Oh that our popular Clergie either would or could looke beyond Luther. They might then learn more manners towards Kings, from Irenaeus, Tertullian, ChryÅ¿oÅ¿tome, BaÅ¿il and to qualifie their ignorant zeales or their malicious knowledge. Let them take one rule for all to Å¿peake honourably of the perÅ¿ons of KINGS from Nazianzen, in his diÅ¿courÅ¿e with ConÅ¿tans the Arrian. He doth not proclaime him Pharaoh, or an Idolater, or (quod quidam fecit) That Tophet is prepared of old, and for the King. I dare not begin to reckon, opus erit viatico. But benignifica natura tua, Domine AuguÅ¿te, intelligit Å¿ingularis & admirabilis Å¿apientia tua, aequum videri debet Å¿anctitati tuae glorioÅ¿iÅ¿Å¿ime AuguÅ¿te, dignantiÅ¿Å¿ime imperator, Å¿ancte Rex, loquuturus Å¿um tecum, cum honore regni & fideitus, and theÅ¿e honourable termes to an Arrian. And 4. hundred Fathers of the Church Å¿pake no other language at Ariminum to an Arrian.

But the Church of God is as the JewiÅ¿h Temple twice built. And as at the latter raiÅ¿ing of it, the old men who had Å¿eene the glory of the former wept in memory of it, for I doubt not but the grave Divines in this, and other Churches, who have Å¿eene the glory of the former part of the Church in the writings of the fathers, doe weepe to Å¿ee it in this latter age built up indeed of Å¿pecious names, and outÅ¿ides of Religion, but all operative faith, devotion ChaÅ¿tity, Temperance, Patience, Obedience even to Kings is made a queÅ¿tion. The Pope he lead is in the front of the latter part of the Church againÅ¿t the right of the Kings. Hee that in former times Å¿ware, in eo per quem reges regnant, He whom the Florentine HiÅ¿tory can informe, that his Å¿upremacie was not derived from an obÅ¿cure place of Scripture or two. But from the Emperours removing his Court from Ravenna; Å¿ince which time not Kings, but Popes are Gods; and the Societie of JeÅ¿us, that Å¿laughter-HouÅ¿e of Kings, can change a Text for his holineÅ¿Å¿e, My Å¿one feare thou God and the Pope, Church-men are exempt from the power of Kings Å¿aith Samuel Sa. A IeÅ¿uite: A Roman Catholike rebelling is no traytor Å¿aith the Å¿ame Samuel Sa. Sexcentis verÅ¿ibus eorum impuritas traloqu nemo poteÅ¿t, in Å¿o much as tis a proverb in Quiccardine it is the propertie of the Church to hate the King.

There is in theÅ¿e latter times another faction againÅ¿t the King
who cry, but with the DonatiÅ¿ts, Quid nobis imperatori? And as the PapiÅ¿ts. Dominus Deus noÅ¿ter papa, Å¿o theÅ¿e Dominus Deus noÅ¿ter conÅ¿iÅ¿torium, presby â¢ erianum. But that you ever Å¿ufficiently deteÅ¿t that kind of government, I will give you one of their phraÅ¿es from the BiÅ¿hop of WincheÅ¿ter, their Church (Å¿ay they) is the houÅ¿e (or rather their private houÅ¿es the Church) and the Commonwealth but the hangings, now the hangings muÅ¿t be made fit for the houÅ¿e not the houÅ¿e for the hangings. And if the King and his Princes be too high for their holy houÅ¿e, they muÅ¿t cut them Å¿horter and with the help of an AnabaptiÅ¿t lay them even with the ground But we have as yet no Å¿uch rebellious cuÅ¿tome, nor I hope ever Å¿hall; nor the Churches to God. Let the Clergie for their obedience imitate holy Samuel to Saul, Eliah to Ahab, who by Å¿peciall commiÅ¿Å¿ion told him, not his people of his Å¿innes. Imitate Jeremie in the priÅ¿on, Daniel in the denne. Amos Å¿trucke through the Temples, Zacharias murthered betweene the porch and the Altar, ChriÅ¿t our MaÅ¿ter under Herod, Tiberius, Å¿uffering under Pontius Pilate, the ApoÅ¿tles under Caligula, Claudius, Nero, Domitian, Saint John in a Tubbe of Oyle, ChriÅ¿tian BiÅ¿hops for many hundred yeares under Tyrants, Idolaters, AtheiÅ¿ts, none of all theÅ¿e reviled their Princes, while they were alive. LaÅ¿t of all remember that Saint Bernard, Fidem â¢ onorum amiÅ¿Å¿ione, exilio, morte non prodam, terramincolo, quaÅ¿i Å¿emper migraturus. And Saint ChryÅ¿oÅ¿t. In EpiÅ¿tola ad Cyrac: will the King or the Queene baniÅ¿h me. The earth is the Loras and the fulneÅ¿Å¿e thereof; will hee cutt me in peeces? I can remember EÅ¿ay, will hee caÅ¿t me into the Sea? Ionas. If into the furnance? The three Children. If to the Lions? Daniel. If Å¿tone me? Saint Stephen. If behead mee? Saint John, LaÅ¿tly (for I dare not rebell) will hee take away my whole eÅ¿tate and Å¿ubÅ¿tance from mee? that of Iob, nudus exivi ex utero matris meae & nudus revertar. This for the Church: Quis e clero, if like the Primitive Fathers, may Å¿ay unto the King, Quid agis? What doeÅ¿t thou?

div.head: 2. Quis ex optimatibus regni? May Å¿ay unto the KING what doeÅ¿t thou.
div.p: Were it not thinke you a very ungratefull Å¿ight to behold a Bull or an Vnicorne puÅ¿hing at the Lion? or the Falcon to Å¿eize upon the Eagle? So, and much more unÅ¿eemely were it for the Princes of the Land to queÅ¿tion their naturall King, or to reprehend his government, otherwiÅ¿e then by adviÅ¿e and humble intreatie. And here I have no minde at this time to undervalue the perÅ¿ons and honours of the Princes of the Land, though but in a comparative way, in that the people will conceive all Å¿poken abÅ¿olutely, which may be delivered by way of compariÅ¿on, and with the King only, pro quo caeteri, &c. And Å¿o have their lives in no honour. And their deaths in contempt and deriÅ¿ion, a fault too generall in this kingdome at this day.

John a Prince â¢ n IÅ¿rael Å¿lew his MaÅ¿ter, he had peace becauÅ¿e he had a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion Å¿aith IuÅ¿tin Martyr. But had Zimri peace that Å¿lew his MaÅ¿ter? David a Prince under Saul tooke up foure hunddred men, but with no intent to oppoÅ¿e the perÅ¿on of Saul, but to preÅ¿erve himÅ¿elfe: And Hugo Grotius grants that to have beene lawfull under the government and law of the Iewes, which is not under the law of ChriÅ¿tians we being bound to more perfect patience and obedience in regard of better promiÅ¿es concerning another kingdome, Å¿o that David caÅ¿e is no preÅ¿ident for us; moreover there is no neceÅ¿Å¿itie to thinke that David intended Å¿o much as a defenÅ¿ive war againÅ¿t Saul, but rather as the Iewes under Antiochus to depart into the wilderneÅ¿Å¿e; and defend himÅ¿elfe againÅ¿t the wild beaÅ¿ts, or to take Å¿ome townes of the PhiliÅ¿tims, untill the day of the death of Saul; Thus dum timuit oleum Å¿ervavit inimicum: All that David did when he could have cut his throate, was that he cut off the skirt of his garment, and even of this he repented, percuÅ¿Å¿it eum cor ejus: And it is this day a tradition amongÅ¿t the Iewes Å¿aith Lyranus, that David was puniÅ¿hed in his death reÅ¿pectively to this Å¿inne, that no clothes could keepe him warme, quia oram vestis Sauli abÅ¿cidit, in vestibus, quibus opertus erat, non calefiebat. There is ground for this in the booke of Kings: But
whether true or no, ficta arguunt, the morall is good. Princeps non eÅ¿t auÅ¿teroris verbienÅ¿e faedandus, nec vel ultimae Å¿uper fluae actionis corum quaÅ¿i finbriam vituperando decorpere preÅ¿um â¢ mus. AbÅ¿alom a Prince Davids Å¿onne rebells with the raireÅ¿t pretence, that both Religion and JuÅ¿tice could make for him, forÅ¿ooth that neither were duely executed in the land; he would doe it, yea and that Å¿peedily, in the gates of the Citie; but marke his end, Å¿uÅ¿penÅ¿us erat quaÅ¿i in patibulo, he was gibbeted without a Hangman, tranÅ¿fixus tribus Å¿agittis. 1. For diÅ¿obedience to his naturall Father, 2. For oppoÅ¿ing his naturall Soveraigne. 3. For Å¿poyling both Church and Å¿tate, under Å¿hew of Religion and JuÅ¿tice even when he lay with his Fathers Concubines upon the houÅ¿e toppe: And let all the enemies of the Lord the King bee as the young man is.

div.head: 3. Quis e MagiÅ¿tratibus regni? May Å¿ay unto the King what doeÅ¿t thou?
div.p:
A vinculis delictorum liberi Å¿unt reges Å¿aith Saint AmbroÅ¿e, and Saint AuÅ¿tin, to moderate the zeale of any inferour MagiÅ¿trate affirmes, if they command any thing, it is not to command but a preÅ¿umption, and obedience to them, proficiet ad paenam non ad premium quam ad contumeliam pertinet creatoris ut contempto Domino colamur Å¿erai & Å¿preto imperatore adorentur comites. No counÅ¿ell or Sanedrim could lawfully queÅ¿tion MoÅ¿es; who was no King but Legatus Dei. HowÅ¿oever Philo in honour of him Å¿tiles him King. There is no queÅ¿tion but the generall counÅ¿ell of a kingdome is the moÅ¿t incomparable medium of preferring both King and people, that the reaÅ¿on of man can poÅ¿Å¿ibly invent: But then the power of it muÅ¿t be onely directive not coercive. For I would aske by what law? by the Kings? No man is bound to give a prejudiciall judgement againÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe, and if any equall have no power over an equall much leÅ¿Å¿e an inferior over a Å¿uperior. Lawes made by the King are not Buchanans, to tye him down under the judgement and cenÅ¿ure of his people, but they are Organs or inÅ¿truments of the power that governeth, at once thereby to reach the whole people, not coactively to binde the legislator, for the K. In whom humane power doth reÅ¿ide, is a perÅ¿on that cannot by his owne power be controlled much leÅ¿te by the power of any Å¿ubject; moreover every active abilitie whether in nature or in morals
is (per Å¿e) cauÅ¿e or principall of alteration corruptively in another body, not in the body in the which it Å¿elfe reÅ¿ides. Wherefore if Divines or Lawyers affirme obligation in Princes to their laws, they teach herein only the bond of conÅ¿cience. They are not Idonei judices, they appeale Å¿traight to God. Tibi Å¿oli peccavi. But to put an end to all queÅ¿tioning of Kings by any under MagiÅ¿trate whatÅ¿oever; I require an anÅ¿wer to the Law of God in theÅ¿e following queÅ¿tions. Who queÅ¿tioned Saul for Å¿laying the PrieÅ¿ts? did the Sanedrim? who queÅ¿tioned Salomon for his revolt to Idolatry? did the Sanedrim? who queÅ¿tioned Ioram a Paracide, and 6. times a murtherer of his Nobles? did the Sanedrim? who Ioas for his Idolatry and Å¿laying the High PrieÅ¿t did the Sanedrim? who queÅ¿tioned TheodoÅ¿ius for murthering 6000. innocent Å¿oules? who queÅ¿tioned ConÅ¿tance, Valens? Julian the ApoÅ¿tate? who traduced their perÅ¿ons and dignities? who offered them tumultuous affronts? unleÅ¿Å¿e wee will skill more in Religion then the former part of the JewiÅ¿h and ChriÅ¿tian world, DeÅ¿inamus ogganire, & plura reges percontari. Remember that of Cicero Regum haec Å¿unt imperia animadverte, & edicto pare, & preter rogitatum Å¿i loquare moriere. And that of the PerÅ¿ian King, mementote parendum vobis eÅ¿Å¿e magis quam Å¿uadendum, even the fundamentall lawes of this kingdome, are by chance or good providence, plaine for the unqueÅ¿tioned power of the King, by any lower MagiÅ¿trate; Thomas of WalÅ¿ingham Å¿peakes from a Parliament held at Lincolne, An. 130. That the King of England from their preeminence and cuÅ¿tome at all times have not to anÅ¿wer before any Judge either EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall or civill. And Henry or Brachton cites a fundamentall of this land, that if any thing bee to bee obtained of the King (Cum breve non currat contra Regem) there is nothing left to them but intreatie and prayers, that hee would correct himÅ¿elfe; which if hee pleaÅ¿e not to doe it is enough that he expect the Lord from heaven as his only revengers. De Chartis Regis facta Regum nec juÅ¿ticiaris nec privatae perÅ¿onae debent diÅ¿putare. For certainely if there be in a Common-wealth, a reluctancie between two governments each watching its advantage and prioritie, it cannot be but as EÅ¿au and Iacob Å¿trugled in the wombe; Å¿o theÅ¿e in the Å¿tate will breed convulÅ¿ion fits, each contending who Å¿hall come forth in government, one of
them at length will come forth with Å¿carlet Å¿trings on his hands and bloudie banners. If a body have two heads they will not eaÅ¿ily agree upon motion. To end this queÅ¿tioning by MagiÅ¿trates wee will call Tertullian. Reges Å¿unt Å¿uper omnes homines & ante omnes Deos: And that proverb of the Rabines, Nulla Creatura Iudicat Rogem.

div.head: Quis e populo, May dare Å¿ay unto the KING what doest thou.
div.p:
GOd bleÅ¿Å¿e this poore people, it is totus in queÅ¿tionibus, buÅ¿ie in Å¿peculations & queÅ¿tions concerning things that do not much concerne them, they have beene in Divinitie long agoe, as whether faith onely, or good workes juÅ¿tifie, and Å¿uch like queÅ¿tions, the Divines have been vehement in thoÅ¿e diÅ¿putes, and the people conceivd Å¿traight matter of Å¿alvation to be in the knowledge of them, then they undertake to diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e the queÅ¿tion, in concluÅ¿ion believe nothing but their own phantaÅ¿ies, and reÅ¿olve to do no good works at all: Then whether the Common-prayer be not diÅ¿ervice, new EngliÅ¿h, for the new Religion, of whom it may be fitly Å¿aid as Tullie of Antho â¢ y, for his pientiÅ¿Å¿imus, quod verbum latino Å¿ermone non est, id ad tuam Å¿ingularem pretatem exprimendam inventum eÅ¿t: Whether kneeling at the Sacrament (that tremendum myÅ¿terium of the commemoration of ChriÅ¿ts paÅ¿Å¿ion bee not Idolatry; whether JeÅ¿u-worÅ¿hip be lawfull, and that reÅ¿olved to their hands, whether to worÅ¿hip God in entrance to his houÅ¿e in the preÅ¿ence of his Angels, Å¿aith Terullian, be not Å¿uperÅ¿titione, O tempora. Whether we may repeate the Lords Prayer that Idol? O mores, whether the Å¿igne of the CroÅ¿Å¿e, uÅ¿ed in Tertullians time be not now popery. O ridiculum! but I may not excuÅ¿Å¿e the reÅ¿t by name Å¿o few, come wee neerer to the Text, whether if our Clergie will not preach unto us Å¿uch PhariÅ¿iacall, Å¿editious, ignorant, Diabolicall doctrine, wee may not chuÅ¿e others in a caÅ¿e Å¿o concerning the deÅ¿truction of our Å¿oules. And then whether if the King HimÅ¿elfe will not conforme to our vaine Å¿enÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e religions, (Å¿o many now for number infinite, for qualitie Å¿o blaÅ¿phemous that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible for one man to know them all, and for rationall man
to practice any of them) wee may not queÅ¿tion his government? whether to make the queÅ¿tion more Å¿emblable) a King in a State, bee not like a Marriner in a Å¿hip? if one will not, another muÅ¿t. The Marriners thought Å¿o in the laÅ¿t tumult, vix vera eÅ¿Å¿e niÅ¿i cunctanter crederem, niÅ¿i his oculis videram. In Å¿um, whether both for Religion and civil policie we may not as we have done to the Clergie, Å¿o to the King put up inÅ¿olent queÅ¿tions. Quid agis? Why doÅ¿t thou rule otherwiÅ¿e then we pleaÅ¿e to be ruled our Å¿elves. O that my head were a fountaine of teares, &c. Jerem.

div.head: 1. For Religion.
div.p:
We read of rebellion intended againÅ¿t AhaÅ¿huerus, 2 HeÅ¿ter ver. 21.22. No reaÅ¿on Å¿et downe, but in diebus illis, and what were thoÅ¿e dayes? you might know them by the Å¿tory. AhaÅ¿uerus had married EÅ¿ter his Queene a vertuous woman, but of another Religion. Bigthan and Thares, Tis like were croÅ¿Å¿ed in the match, but Å¿ee they draw their arguments from popular heads, to intereÅ¿t 127. provinces in the rebellion. AhaÅ¿uerus our King matcheth with a Jew, one of a Religion hated among us, one that cares neither for Mithra nor WamaÅ¿dres, one brought in to ruinate the eÅ¿tablish'd religion in PerÅ¿ia, which by our Law ought not to be altered. Thus they are zealous on the Å¿uddaine, as the faÅ¿hion of the world is; This jealouÅ¿ie delivered downe and digeÅ¿ted by a prevailing faction in the people, they forthwith (although there be no cauÅ¿e) are ready tumultuatim to runne up to the King with Quid agis? Why doÅ¿t thou change our Religion. Good people) for Å¿o I may rhetorically call them) if you intend a new religion take not rebellion in your way, for a thing that I will tell you in Luthers reformation, when was more need then now is, the rule of obedience was not duely obÅ¿erved, and there fell in or upon that reformation 100. thouÅ¿and of the people, before then that you need a reformation, before you adventure upon the dangers. Barclay accuÅ¿eth Luther for it, I dare not defend him, I finde him in his booke, Contra regem Angliae, very familiar and impudent to the King, Å¿toliditas veÅ¿tra, aÅ¿initas veÅ¿tra, cornicula avum, aut regem naÅ¿ci aut fatuum; and I wiÅ¿h there be no Å¿uch Sheimies Å¿uch felly tounged reformers
abroad in this our pious reformation. Barclay chargeth Luther, yet farther of the death of all thoÅ¿e people, that when he had moved them to rebellion, and could not accompliÅ¿h his owne ends, he was the firÅ¿t that moved the MagiÅ¿trate to ruine and deÅ¿troy them, all how true God knowes, but this the people may know is true in Policie in States men, under the larve of Religion to draw the people to one Å¿ide, but if they faile in their plots and ambitious Projects, they to preferre themÅ¿elves muÅ¿t be the firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t active in cutting the peoples Throates whom they have Å¿tirred up.

Againe, in the Reformation after the death of Å¿o many thouÅ¿ands, and there iÅ¿Å¿ued forth Å¿o many SchiÅ¿mes from the Anarchie, that holy Melancton who loved not Poperie confeÅ¿Å¿ed for unities Å¿ake, they muÅ¿t all returne to the Church of Rome againe and Prot: in his An: on CaÅ¿Å¿: Porf: Å¿peaks little leÅ¿Å¿e, better to endure one extreamitie then Twentie, better admit of one tyrannicall Religion then a hundred. And I pray God it bee not the effect, and reÅ¿ultance of our many SchiÅ¿mes and diÅ¿tractions in our Church at this day. To come with queÅ¿tions contradiction to a King, for Religion was not heard of in the IewiÅ¿h Government. The Law in Deutren mie 13.6. was if thy brother or thy Å¿onne, or thy wife, or thy friend intice thee to Idolatry, Å¿iÅ¿tas coscoram judice, not if thy Father, or thy Husband, or thy Judge, for certaine not thy King. The manner of BalthaÅ¿ars depoÅ¿ition for abuÅ¿ing Gods Religion and Temple, is very remarkable by all good Subjects. None of his Subjects muÅ¿t dare to draw up the order no, a hand writing out of the wall from God, muÅ¿t declare it, and when it was there none of all the people were able to read it, Å¿o Å¿trange a thing to a Å¿ubject is a depoÅ¿ition of his King, no nor the AÅ¿trologers nor South-Å¿ayers, no nor the Devill himÅ¿elfe is able to underÅ¿tand it. Daniell is Å¿ent for, he only by divine revelation is able to read, and what is it. Mene, Mene, tekell uparÅ¿in, God not the people hath numbred thy Kingdome and finiÅ¿hed it, JoÅ¿eph 17. chap. 36. Tells us of the Å¿ect of the PhariÅ¿ees, who to the number of Å¿ixe thouÅ¿and in zeale to their hypocriticall Religion, were in a covenant by themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t CaeÅ¿ar, Å¿ome of that number came to our Saviour with that queÅ¿tion (for that is Å¿till
their forme) is it lawfull to give Tribute unto CaeÅ¿ar. They are reÅ¿olved not to doe it before, and theÅ¿e Sectaries proved the ruine of the IewiÅ¿h Government, with whom Docter IackÅ¿on compares the SchiÅ¿maticks, of his, and theÅ¿e times, growing on Å¿o faÅ¿t, that both he and Sir Walter Ral. 2. HiÅ¿t. Å¿pake out of propheticke wiÅ¿dome, that they would hazard the ruine both of this Church and State, and they would force it into ã in non-Latin alphabet ã and confuÅ¿ion. For indeed what elÅ¿e can bee expected, when every one may aÅ¿Å¿ume his owne Religion, and Å¿uch a one as may encourage him to contradict the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed government of the Church, on the one hand, and the fundamentall Lawes of the Land bee obÅ¿cured on the other, and the MajeÅ¿tie and power of the Kings perÅ¿on contemned, what remaines but we may Å¿ay over this Church as Iugurtha over Rome. O urbem venalem & lite perituram Å¿i emptorem invenerit.

div.head: 2. For Civill Government.
div.p:
As the people for Religion may not queÅ¿tion the King, Å¿o neither for the policie and civill affaires, may they Å¿ay unto him, what doeÅ¿t thou. And here the people are furniÅ¿hed (I know not whence) with as many queÅ¿tions to moleÅ¿t the quiet of the Å¿tate, as they have beene of late to diÅ¿turbe the peace of the Church. And firÅ¿t may not his own Lawes Å¿ay unto him Quid agis? Directive they may coactive, they neither may nor can; if the King be in an errour, he can make new lawes to defend his errour, Å¿aith Saint AuguÅ¿tine, and Sir Walter Ralleigh, reprehends Bracton though a PhilachriÅ¿t, for Å¿aying that a King is King by the Law, Me ito debet res tribuere regi quod lex attribuit ei nam lex facit ut ipÅ¿e Å¿it Rex. Whereas Å¿aith Sir Walter, Bracton aÅ¿cribes this power to humane Law, hee is miÅ¿t ken, for Kings are made by God, and Lawes Divine, and by humane Lawes are only declared to be King. But is he not a King by our election? Election doth not make him King although, unleÅ¿Å¿e he had beene choÅ¿en he had not beene Å¿uch. As they are to Å¿ay of good worke, they are via ad regnum non cauÅ¿a regnandi, Å¿o may wee of election, tis not the cauÅ¿e but the way to the kingdome, and Å¿o we find in Scripture, where the people
choÅ¿e, God made the King it is not nos, but Ego poÅ¿ui regem Å¿uper IÅ¿rael, and it was Gods admirable wiÅ¿dome, when the world could no longer Å¿ubÅ¿ist under paternall Government, in that men and malice increaÅ¿ing in the world, paternall indulgences would not doe right reÅ¿pectively, every mans injuries both expreÅ¿ly in the IewiÅ¿h government and in other States by the Law of reaÅ¿on doe prompt them to elect one man as their common Father, that this one man, this common Father, this King not intereÅ¿ted in private reÅ¿pects might diÅ¿tribute IuÅ¿tice impartially, and puniÅ¿h offences in equitie: and alÅ¿o that the people by their owne act of election might bee obliged the more to obey him, although he proved rigid and auÅ¿tere, as they would and ought to obey their naturall Father, which act God evermore confirmes in Heaven, this may appeare better in a Å¿imilitude. Originall Å¿inne is remitted in BaptiÅ¿me, but not ex opere operato, yet if there bee no opus operatum there is (by vertue of the covenant ordinario, no remiÅ¿Å¿ion of the Å¿inne; and after opus operatum it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible for the PrieÅ¿t to revoake the Å¿in againe remitted in heaven.
